summary.value:
[Thesis]
Does anthropomorphism offer a theory of character? Narratologists have struggled to define literary character in terms which do not assume the inherent recognizability of human characters to human readers. A digital, quantitative index of anthropomorphism reveals the ways in which named and unnamed characters, animals, objects exist along formal continuua rather than emerge as qualitative concepts about which humans make or do not make categorical errors. The existence of such a spectrum will confirm a concept existing in linguistics and further developed in critical theory by Mel Chen, of an animacy hierarchy, “a particular political grammar...which conceptually arranges human life, disabled life, animal life, plant life, and forms of nonliving material in orders of value and priority” (13).

Nearly all narratological definitions of character identify it as the anthropomorphic element of narrative. Even the most rigidly structuralist theories of narrative retain some assumptions about the human-like qualities of a literary character. When Roland Barthes theorizes in S/Z that literary characters are in essence merely “an impersonal network of symbols” (93), he still admits that the conventions of formal realism often make it possible to substitute a name for that network. Though Barthes does not elaborate on the logic of that exchange, we find implicit even in his account the suggestion that impersonal symbols somehow cohere into a recognizable bounded whole that could be legible under the sign of a proper name. One suspects, despite Barthes’ rigorous anti-humanism, that this exchange is facilitated by the concept of the human.

We reimagine anthropomorphism as a quantitative form, a human-likeness measured as the probability of appearing as a human to a model trained on the syntactic and semantic markers of humanness. We then go beyond the frequent approach to anthropomorphism which focuses on its definition as a category error, a qualitative boundary.

Previous theory was caught in a contradiction between assuming anthropomorphism was constitutive and productive of human literary character as well as a category error, a “character effect,” which might naively attribute to human personhood where none exists—presenting an ethical danger of confusing, reifying, or destabilizing the concept of the person. This is still a problem for animal studies, which remains skeptical of literary investments of inaccurate representations of animal life rather than engaging the true biological and biopolitical reality of animal life.

Does, then, a turn to a quantitative notion of anthropomorphism help us get beyond this antinomy within theories of anthropomorphism and character? Digital methods, by inhering within the syntactic and semantic aspects of the text, analyze character not in referential terms but in formal ones. It is also able to produces a new kind of relationality between the concepts of the object, the animal, the human, and the literary character, situating them along a formal continuum of anthropomorphic representation.



[Hypotheses]
Animals become less frequent in fiction during the inter-war period.

The more recognizable as a conventional character a textual entity is to human readers, the higher probability it will appear as a “human” noun or name to a probabilistic model trained solely on the syntactic and semantic components of that noun.

Major (named) characters will appear as more human-like to the model than minor (named) characters.

Named characters will appear as more human-like than unnamed human nouns.

Named and unnamed humans will appear as more human-like than animal nouns.

Humans and animals will appear as more human-like than object nouns.

Women characters will appear as less human-like than male ones.

Objects associated with industrial processes, force and will appear more human-like than the raw materials of those processes: for example, the steel-mill will appear more human-like than the steel, the train will appear more human-like than its carriages.

What is responsible for the human-likeness of entities within narrative is less their categorical identity than in their embeddedness certain syntactic and semantic formulations (e.g. subjective rather than objective relation to verbs; attached to cognitive and emotive words; attached to words implying intentional action).

Around the turn of the 20th century, human nouns appear more object-like than in earlier periods, whereas animal nouns appear more human-like, producing an apparent convergence between these ontological categories.

(Ian Watt’s hypothesis:) The rise of the novel correlates with a rise of interiority (measured as verbs of cognition, etc) and specificity (measured as diversity, range, and detail of character-markers) in the construction of its characters.

The elaboration of a spectrum--from most object-like to most human-like--will confirm a concept existing in linguistics and further developed in critical theory by Mel Chen, of an animacy hierarchy, “a particular political grammar...which conceptually arranges human life, disabled life, animal life, plant life, and forms of nonliving material in orders of value and priority” (13).


[Experimental design]
Based on the adjectives which modify a noun or character name; the noun it posses; and the verbs for which it is a subject and object; can a logistic regression classify human vs. object? Along this probability spectrum, where do animals lie?

attributes.title: HRV changes after cognitive and emotional challenges in high and low ruminators
attributes.description:
Abstract

Background: Recovery from stress is a predictive factor for cardiovascular health and HRV is suggested to be an index of how well people physiologically recover from stress. Biofeedback interventions that include guided breathing have shown to be effective in increasing HRV and facilitate stress recovery.  
Objective: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a brief app-based biofeedback breathing intervention (BioBase) in enhancing physiological recovery among employees who were induced to cognitive and emotional stress in the laboratory.
Methods: In total 75 full-time employees took part. Inter-beat-intervals (RR) were recorded continuously for 5 min. of baseline, followed by cognitive and emotional stress induction. The session ended with a 5 min. recovery period during which participants were randomly allocated in three conditions: control, mindfulness or app-based biofeedback breathing (BioBase). Subjective tension was assessed at the end of each period.
Results: Levels of subjective tension significantly increased following the stress induction. HRV significantly decreased following the stress period. At the recovery phase there was a significant increase in the root mean square of successive differences (p=.002), the percentage of successive RR that differ by >50ms (p=.008) and high frequency (p=.012) for those in the BioBase breathing condition than the mindfulness and the control group.
Conclusions: Biofeedback breathing interventions digitally delivered through a commercially available app. can be effective in facilitating stress recovery among employees. These findings contribute to m-health literature on the beneficial effects of brief biofeedback interventions on employees’ cardiovascular health.

q1.value: Exploring the effects of a brief biofeedback breathing session on physiological recovery after cognitive and emotional stress in employees: a randomised study

q2.value: Olga Chelidoni, Mark Cropley, David Plans

q3.value: Biofeedback and mindfulness have been suggested to confer beneficial effects for individuals physical health. But their effectiveness on employees stress recovery has not yet been tested. Therefore we will investigate the effectiveness of these two methods  in increasing HRV among employees  following stress exposure

q4.value: No specific hypothesis are being formulated as we aim to compare the effectiveness of two methods in increasing HRV post stress.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q14.value: Time, money and personnel constrained data collection to 75.

question.value: We manipulated condition in the posts stress period. The three levels of this variable are : biofeedback breathing, mindfulness and control.

Outcome variables is HRV (RMSSD, pnn50, HF) of each participant during the recovery period (post stress). HRV is recorded via the Polar Range smartwatch and heart sensor and then analysed in Artiifact .
We used three between group one way ANOVA with group  as the between factor with three levels (biofeedback breathing, mindfulness, control).

q20.value: Non normally distributed data are log transformed.

q21.value: We use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the group differences and follow up tests suggest that the results are significantly different .

q23.value: If a subject does have complete data then that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: It might be that some demographic traits and external factors may be related to HRV. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, work hours per week) and fatigue, sleepiness, smoking and fitness status with baseline HRV.

attributes.title: The effect of transparently unfair penalties on compliance with business safety regulations

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The effect of transparently unfair penalties on compliance with business safety regulations

other.value: We will explore the behavioral results based on the post-experimental questionnaire.

sample.value: We target to recruit N = 400 participants in the lab. In case we do not reach the target sample size, we aim at collecting an additional online sample via an established online research platform (e.g., Prolific Academic or Amazon Mechanical Turk).

analyses.value:
The analyses will be conducted using the r-package "lme4" to test linear-mixed models. The dependent variable is relative compliance (percentage of compliance per round). Predictors will be entered as specified below for each research question. The predictors income and audit probability have three categorical levels. The lowest category will serve as reference category (dummy coding). 

1.) Linear regression; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: income level (refers to variation within the company types), relative compliance costs, audit probability. In a second model the conditions are considered by entering transparency and procedural fairness of penalties as predictors, as well as the respective interactions.

2.) Linear regression; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: business type, transparency, business type x transparency; only conditions with same penalty rates for small and big size companies considered.

3.) Linear regression; dependent variable: relative compliance; predictors: business type, transparency, procedural fairness of penalties, all two-way interactions of the predictors and the three-way interaction.

All models will include a random effect for participants to account for repeated measures.

outliers.value: In case of an additional online sample, we will perform further analyses where we exclude participants who fail the attention checks.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variable is relative compliance with safety regulations, measured as amount of paid safety costs divided by the due safety costs.

Participants are informed that during the study they will take on the role of a business owner that manufactures toys. In each round of the experiment they receive turnover (income) which varies for both small and big size businesses over the rounds, but is always higher for the big size businesses in comparison to the small size businesses. They have to spend a certain amount of their income as compliance costs to adhere to safety rules. This means they get a screen that informs them about their income in the respective round and the due safety compliance costs, as well as the chance to be audited by the responsible authorities and the potential penalties for noncompliance. Business income, safety compliance costs, and audit probabilities vary over the 18 rounds of the experiment. When making the decision whether to (fully) comply with the safety regulations in each round, participants have to fill in a form. The final payoff is determined by one randomly drawn round and based on the compliance decision in this round and whether there was an audit (and a potential penalty). 

Several measures will be collected in the post experimental survey and are defined as follows: - Memory/attention check (5 options per item) – Risk propensity (6 items) on a 7-point Likert-type scale – Norm Following (7 items) on a 5-point Likert-type scale – Perceived fairness (1 or 2 items depending on transparent or non-transparent condition) on a 7-point Likert-type scale.

conditions.value:
The study constitutes a mixed-design. In eight different conditions, we test the influence of business income (two levels; small size company vs. large size company), procedural fairness of penalties (two levels; payback + 50% for both company sizes vs. payback + 50% for small size companies and payback + 150% for big size companies), and transparency of penalties (two levels; information on penalty rate for other companies not provided vs. information on penalty rate for other companies provided) on the compliance with safety regulations. These three independent variables are all manipulated between participants. Fairness of penalties and transparency of penalties are manipulated on the session level (the same for all participants within a certain experimental session), while company size is manipulated within sessions (i.e., randomly assigned to each participant within a session).

Within-subject factors: All participants will go through 18 rounds of compliance decisions. Each round has a unique combination of the parameters income, compliance costs due, and audit probability (3x2x3 levels). Income is either 1000, 1500, or 2000 ECU (small size companies) or 1500, 2000, or 2500 ECU (big size companies). Compliance costs are either 20% or 40% of the income earned per round. The audit probability is set at 10%, 15%, or 20%.

hypothesis.value:
Theories of corporate illegality (e.g., Baucus, 1994; Coleman, 1987; Finney & Lesieur, 1982) assume three preconditions for illegal behavior of businesses: (1) the motivation to break the law in order to achieve goals or to ensure survival; (2) the opportunity to engage in illegal behavior; and (3) no effective controls to deter from illegal behavior. In line with the economics-of-crime paradigm (Becker, 1968), the traditional view is that illegal behavior, as - for instance - noncompliance with safety standards and regulations, should be negatively related to the level of deterrence. Accordingly, high compared to low penalty levels are expected to result in more pronounced compliance. The aim of the present study is to investigate whether the effect of penalties on compliance can be overshadowed in case of perceived procedural unfairness. We investigate if the positive effect of higher penalties on compliance is attenuated when the penalty scheme is unfair and transparent. In such a situation unintended opposite effects may occur, for instance due to reactance by disadvantaged parties (i.e., big size companies) resulting in lower compliance.

1.) Do income level, the relative compliance costs, and the audit probability influence compliance with safety regulations in different conditions of transparency and penalty schemes?

2.) Does the business type (small vs. big size) in the conditions with the same penalty rate influence compliance with safety regulations in conditions with and without transparency?

3.) How does the higher penalty rate for big size businesses (procedurally unfair penalty scheme) affect relative compliance in comparison to the equal penalty rate for small and big businesses (procedurally fair penalty scheme) in conditions with and without transparency?

attributes.title: Having feet to walk a mile in someone‘s shoes: The relationship between personality and perspective-taking in political discussions

q1.value: Having feet to walk a mile in someone‘s shoes: The relationship between personality and perspective-taking in political discussions

q3.value:
Empathy, including perspective-taking as a cognitive facet of empathy, has been found to promote pro-social behavior and intentions for compromising, reduce prejudices and enhance the quality of discussions. These are important components of any successful human cohabitation from dyadic relationships to nationwide democratic processes. 
This study aims to investigate how personality traits are related to ability and drive for perspective-taking in the context of political discussions. 
After the participants have filled out a questionnaire, three text vignettes will be presented to them and they will be asked to report their perceived ability and drive for perspective-taking in relation to the fictive person of the vignette. The purpose of this is to take into account that the opinion of the person whose perspective is to be taken might have an influence on the ability and drive for perspective-taking. The overall drive and ability for perspective-taking will be extracted using latent-state-trait-modeling and then correlated with Big Five traits and narcissism.

q4.value:
1. High scores on the Big Five trait scales „conscientiousness“, „extraversion“, „openness“ and „agreeableness“ predict high ability and drive for perspective-taking (low-moderate correlations)
    2. A high score on the Big Five trait scale „neuroticism“ predicts low ability and drive for perspective-taking (low correlation)
    3. A high score on a narcissism scale predicts low drive for perspective-taking (no hypothesis regarding degree of correlation) 
    4. The score on a narcissism scale doesn‘t predict ability for perspective-taking (no correlation)

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants will receive the information that it is a study about political discussions but won‘t receive more details about the purpose of the study before they have finished the questionnaire. They will have the opportunity to sign up for more information on the study‘s purpose.

question.value:
The study is a combination of a survey and an experimental vignette study. 

Of the three text vignettes presented to the subject, one exposes the same view as the subject's view, one a view contrary to the view of the subject and one a neutral view. Every subject will receive these three kinds of texts (within-subjects-factor in regards to the degree of concurrence between the participant's and the texts' opinion). To realize this, subjects will be asked about their opinion earlier in the study, so that the texts can be selected accordingly. 

The attached file contains two charts that describe the randomization pattern and the pattern that decides who receives which text.

q9.value: A random number (the day of participant‘s birth date) will determine which type of opinion will be presented with which political/social topic (to ensure that the type of opinion and the topic are not confounded).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
An email will be sent to the „VPN“ distribution list of the Fachschaftsrat Psychologie at Friedrich Schiller University Jena.  The email will contain a link to the survey. 
Furthermore, a message with a link to the survey will be sent to three different WhatsApp groups of psychology students and to a Facebook group of the Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena. 
If this doesn‘t provide a sufficient sample size, more participants will be recruited through distribution lists from other university lists, flyers and personal approach in highly frequented places at the Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, such as in front of the canteen. 

Everyone interested will be able to participate, even though some subjects may be excluded afterwards if they meet one of the criteria which are explained later.

Participants will be able to receive an attestation for participating in the study ("VPN-Stunden") and receive feedback on their responses.

q13.value: The aim is to recruit and analyze the data of at least 200 subjects.

q14.value: The aimed sample size complies with expert's advice on minimum sample sizes for latent-state-trait modeling.

q15.value: Data will be collected for four weeks. If less then 200 subjects will have participated by the end of this time, data collection will continue until the aim of 200 participants is reached or for six more weeks.

question.value: As part of the study, three vignette texts will be presented to the participant. The degree of concurrence between the opinion of the participant and the texts will be manipulated (1x same opinion, 1x opposite opinion, 1x neutral opinion).

    • Presence of diagnosed personality disorders, schizophrenia or autism
    • Personal opinion on three social/political issues
    • Big Five Traits, measured using the German short version of the Big Five Inventory (BFI-K)
    • Narcissism, measured using the German short version of the Narcisistic Admiration and Rivalry Questionnaire (NARQ)
    • Social desirability, measured using the German version of the Soziale-Erwünschtheitsskala-17
    • Ability for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 1
    • Drive for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 1
    • Ability for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 2
    • Drive for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 2
    • Ability for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 3
    • Drive for Perspective-Taking, Vignette 3
Ability and Drive for Perspective-Taking will be measured using the scales „Cognitive Ability“ and „Cognitive Drive“ from the Empathy Components Questionnaire (ECQ) with slightly adapted wording.

The trait component of the drive and ability for perspective-taking will be extracted using a latent-state-trait model that will be tested through statistical model comparison with less restrictive models. 
In the next step, the extracted trait component will be correlated with the corresponding results of the measurement of Big Five traits and narcissism.

Participants that show a divergent response pattern (meaning that their individual means of ability and drive for perspective-taking are above or below two standard deviations of the general mean of the sample) and one of these criteria:
    • expose a value of social desirability two standard deviations above the mean of the sample
    • indicate that they have been diagnosed with a mental disorder
    • are of different nationality than German 
    • don‘t provide information on mental disorder diagnosis or nationality
may be excluded from analyses to control possible effects of social desirability, mental disorders, culture and language comprehension on self-report of ability and drive for perspective-taking.

q23.value:

Full-information-Maximum-Likelihood methods will be used to estimate parameters.

registration_responses.q1: Having feet to walk a mile in someone‘s shoes: The relationship between personality and perspective-taking in political discussions
registration_responses.q3:
Empathy, including perspective-taking as a cognitive facet of empathy, has been found to promote pro-social behavior and intentions for compromising, reduce prejudices and enhance the quality of discussions. These are important components of any successful human cohabitation from dyadic relationships to nationwide democratic processes. 
This study aims to investigate how personality traits are related to ability and drive for perspective-taking in the context of political discussions. 
After the participants have filled out a questionnaire, three text vignettes will be presented to them and they will be asked to report their perceived ability and drive for perspective-taking in relation to the fictive person of the vignette. The purpose of this is to take into account that the opinion of the person whose perspective is to be taken might have an influence on the ability and drive for perspective-taking. The overall drive and ability for perspective-taking will be extracted using latent-state-trait-modeling and then correlated with Big Five traits and narcissism.
registration_responses.q4:
1. High scores on the Big Five trait scales „conscientiousness“, „extraversion“, „openness“ and „agreeableness“ predict high ability and drive for perspective-taking (low-moderate correlations)
    2. A high score on the Big Five trait scale „neuroticism“ predicts low ability and drive for perspective-taking (low correlation)
    3. A high score on a narcissism scale predicts low drive for perspective-taking (no hypothesis regarding degree of correlation) 
    4. The score on a narcissism scale doesn‘t predict ability for perspective-taking (no correlation)

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study is a combination of a survey and an experimental vignette study. 

Of the three text vignettes presented to the subject, one exposes the same view as the subject's view, one a view contrary to the view of the subject and one a neutral view. Every subject will receive these three kinds of texts (within-subjects-factor in regards to the degree of concurrence between the participant's and the texts' opinion). To realize this, subjects will be asked about their opinion earlier in the study, so that the texts can be selected accordingly. 

The attached file contains two charts that describe the randomization pattern and the pattern that decides who receives which text.
registration_responses.q12.question:
An email will be sent to the „VPN“ distribution list of the Fachschaftsrat Psychologie at Friedrich Schiller University Jena.  The email will contain a link to the survey. 
Furthermore, a message with a link to the survey will be sent to three different WhatsApp groups of psychology students and to a Facebook group of the Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena. 
If this doesn‘t provide a sufficient sample size, more participants will be recruited through distribution lists from other university lists, flyers and personal approach in highly frequented places at the Friedrich-Schiller-Universität Jena, such as in front of the canteen. 

Everyone interested will be able to participate, even though some subjects may be excluded afterwards if they meet one of the criteria which are explained later.

Participants will be able to receive an attestation for participating in the study ("VPN-Stunden") and receive feedback on their responses.
registration_responses.q16.question: As part of the study, three vignette texts will be presented to the participant. The degree of concurrence between the opinion of the participant and the texts will be manipulated (1x same opinion, 1x opposite opinion, 1x neutral opinion).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
1. manipulation check

To check whether the goal to experiencing as few as negative feelings as possible is successfully induced, participants will report on the extent to which they tried to experience as few as negative feelings as possible on a 7-point scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 6 (very much).The manipulation of the emotion-related goal will be considered successful if participants in the goal-salient condition reported more effort to experience negative feelings compared to participants in the no-goal control condition. 

2. Emotion regulation questions
For exploration, the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ, Gross & John, 2003) will be included to measure individual differences in daily use of the emotion regulation strategies reappraisal and suppression.

sample.value:
The sample size is calculated by G*power 3.1(Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009), with “F tests, Linear multiple regression: Fixed model, R2 deviation from zero”. The inputted parameters are: a small to medium effect size (f2 = 0.10), α of 0.05, a power of 0.80, and a number of 3 predictors. The estimated sample size is 114. To prevent drop-out and incomplete task performance, we enlarged the sample size by 10% and the plan to recruit 114 * (1 + 10%) = 126 participants. 

It is important to note that, sequential samplings and sequential analyses will be applied to this study. The sequential analyses will follow the instructions in the paper Performing high-powered studies efficiently with sequential analyses (Lakens, 2014).

The data collection plan is done by first decided the interims, and then calculated the boundary alpha. The calculation was done with GroupSeq package in R. For step and step guidance, please see https://osf.io/qtufw/.


The planned data collection consists of 3 interims. That is, the data collection will be separated into 3 phases (times). Phase 1 collects 60% of the participants (n = 74); Phase 2 collects another 25 participants, finishing 80% (n = 99) of the participants; and finally, phase 3 completes the whole data collection, with 126 participants in total recruited.

Below are the parameters used in calculating the boundary alpha.

a) Within the window of the GroupSeq select “-1- Compute Bounds”.
b) Input “#Interim Times: K = 3
c) Unclick the equally spaced interim analyses, and input time 1 = 0.6, time 2 = 0.8, time 3 = 1.
d) Select ‘Two-sided’ bounds.
e) Adopt the default significance level: alpha = 0.05
f) Use Power Family: alpha*t^phi, click ‘CONFIRM FUNCTION’ and use the default parameter (1).

The upper bound Z scores for Phase 1, 2 and 3, are 2.1701, 2.2776, and 2.2437. Accordingly, the boundary alpha for Phase 1 (times 1) is .030, .0228 for phase 2, and .0249 for phase 3.


If the expected difference is significant at the first interim analysis (after 74 participants; with an alpha boundary of .030) the data collection will be stopped.
Otherwise, the data collection will be processed to the second phase. If, after 99 participants, the expected difference is significant (alpha boundary of .028), the data collection will be stopped. Otherwise, the data collection will be continued until 126 participants have been collected.

analyses.value:
Regression analyses will be applied to test the hypotheses (see question 2). Two different regression models will be constructed separately for the two outcome variables (i.e. attention bias towards positive stimuli and attention bias away from negative stimuli.). In both regressions, the predictors are condition (goal-salient vs. non-salient), trait self-control, and the interaction term of condition × trait self-control.

The condition will be coded as dummy variable and the trait self-control is a continuous variable. As an interaction term is included in the analysis, the score on trait self-control will be centered before entered into the regression analysis, to prevent multicollinearity. 

Before doing the analysis, we will check whether the data meet the assumptions for regression analysis. Specifically, we will examine the following assumptions:
•	Linear relationship
•	Multivariate normality
•	No or little multicollinearity
•	No auto-correlation
•	Homoscedasticity

Violation of assumptions will be reported.

outliers.value:
As the dot-probe task will be used in this study, common practices in the dot-probe task will be followed when defining valid answers and outliers (see Glinder, Beckjord, Kaiser, & Compas, 2007; Gray, Baker, Scerif, & Lau, 2016). Valid reaction time data in a single task are those trials in which the probe position is accurately identified, and the response is slower than 200 ms, but quicker than 2000 ms, and within two standard deviations of each participant’s mean response time from the same condition.
When mean reaction times are skewed, analyses will be completed on log transformed data.

Besides, participants’ data will be discarded if participants do one or/and more of the things listed below:
(1) report an age younger than 18 or older than 65;
(2) have outlier value(s) in trait self-control, or/and positive feelings, or/and negative feelings.

dependent.value:
Two outcome variables are measured in this study: 1) attention bias towards positive stimuli and 2) attention bias away from negative stimuli. Attention bias will be measured by a dot-probe task.

Two attention bias indexes will be calculated separately for positive pictures and negative pictures, based on valid response data. For the criterium of valid data, please see the reply to question 6.

The attention bias index for each participant will be calculated by taking the mean response time of trials in which the probe appeared at the location of the neutral picture (incongruent trial reaction times) and subtracting the mean response time of trials in which the probe appeared at the location of the valenced picture (congruent trial reaction times).

conditions.value:
The current preregistered study adopts a between-subject design, with two conditions (i.e. goal-salient condition and non-goal control condition). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions. The goals will be manipulated by instructions. Before the practice trails, participants in the goal-salient condition will read the instruction: “We would like to kindly remind you that emotional pictures will be presented in the task. Please try your best to feel as few negative feelings as possible while completing the task.” After the practice trails and before the formal trails, participants in the goal-salient condition will be remined of this goal again, with the sentence “Please try your best to feel as few negative feelings as possible while completing the formal task.”. Participants in the no-goal control condition will not be confronted with these instructions.
In both conditions, participants will be given the same dot-probe task to measure attentional bias.

hypothesis.value:
This study is one among a series of studies examining the relationship between trait self-control and emotion regulation [for the first two studies, see https://osf.io/j35w8 and https://osf.io/56rg2]. Specifically, this study focuses on one particular emotion regulation strategy, i.e. attention deployment.
The main questions under investigation are whether high self-controllers, compared to low self-controllers, pay 1) more attention to positive stimuli; and 2) less attention to negative stimuli. 
Besides, since self-control is related to accomplishing a long-term goal, this study will also test if an accentuated long-term goal induces more goal-related emotion regulation behavior in high (vs. low) self-controllers. The specific hypotheses are as follows.
H1: (a) High self-controllers demonstrate more attention bias towards positive stimuli, compared to low self-controllers; and 
(b) this stronger attention bias towards positive stimuli among high self-controllers is more prominent when the goal of emotion regulation is highlighted.
H2: (a) High self-controllers show stronger attention bias away from negative stimuli, compared to low self-controllers; and 
 (b) this stronger attention bias away from negative stimuli among high self-controllers is more prominent when the goal of emotion regulation is highlighted.

study_type_other.value: The pictures to be used in this study are from the Open Affective Standardized Image Set (OASIS, Kurdi, Lozano, & Banaji, 2017). A pilot study has been conducted to rate the valence of the pictures.

attributes.title: Prevalence and incidence of post-traumatic stress disorder and post-traumatic stress symptoms in people with chronic somatic diseases: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Prevalence and incidence of post-traumatic stress disorder and post-traumatic stress symptoms in people with chronic somatic diseases: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Frederike Lunkenheimer, Lena Steubl, Patricia Garatva, Harald Baumeister

q3.value: To estimate the prevalence and incidence rates of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and post-traumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) in people with chronic somatic diseases (CD) and following a CD event, respectively.

q4.value:
Specific research questions are:
(1) What are the point (≤ 4 weeks), 12-months and lifetime prevalence rates of PTSD and PTSS in people with CD?
(2) What is the 12-months incidence rate of PTSD and PTSS following a CD event?
(3) What are possible moderators of 
a) prevalence of PTSD and PTSS in people with CD
b) incidence of PTSD and PTSS following a CD event?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: PsycINFO, MEDLINE, and EMBASE will be searched by two independent reviewers (PG & FL) for relevant studies reporting prevalence and/or incidence rates in people with CD with no restriction on publication date, publication status, study type and country with a set of pre-established search strings. Disagreements about eligibility will be discussed, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary. Reference lists of all included studies as well as relevant systematic reviews and meta-analyses will be checked for eligible studies. Eligible studies have to be published in English or German. In case no complete text is available, authors will be contacted. If the full text is still not available, the study will be excluded. If there are studies reporting the same outcome based on the same population sample, only the most comprehensive publication will be included. Only studies in human populations will be included.

q13.value: We developed a sensitive search strategy, meaning we seek for all existing literature according to our review question/s.

question.value:
Main Outcome/s:
Point (≤ 4 weeks), 12-months and lifetime prevalence rate of PTSD and PTSS in people with CD as well as 12-months incidence rate of PTSD and PTSS following a CD event.
Timing and effect measures: Any time-point regarding research question 1 and 3a; regarding research question 2 and 3b: PTSD/PTSS have to be assessed after an CD event occurred.

Additional Outcome/s:
Identification of possible moderators of (a) prevalence and (b) incidence rates: The third review question will be explorative and data-driven. We do not define relevant moderators in advance, but we will extract all investigated moderators from the included studies and prepare them systematically to identify potential relationships.

After duplicate removal, all titles and abstracts identified in the searches will be screened. All papers selected from this step will be reviewed in full text and checked for eligibility criteria
Study selection and data extraction will be conducted by two researchers independently (FL & PG). Disagreements will be resolved by discussion, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary.
In case of multiple outcome measures for the assessment of PTSD/PTSS and CD, data will be extracted according to the following hierarchy: Structured interviews, self-report questionnaires, diagnosis by health care professionals, observer assessment. In case of outcome measures of the same hierarchy level, the most commonly used measure across all included studies will be selected or, if not applicable, one outcome measure is randomly selected.
Extracted data will be cross-checked for completeness.

Data analyses will be performed using Review Manager 5.3. 
Forest plots will be created and used to visually investigate statistical heterogeneity. We will use the I² statistics to quantify statistical heterogeneity across studies. In this review the statistical heterogeneity will be regarded as substantial with an I² > 60%. Only studies showing less than substantial statistical heterogeneity (0-60%) will be pooled. In case of substantial statistical heterogeneity, we will abstain from meta-analytical pooling of outcomes across studies and will only report the range of prevalence and incidence rates, descriptively summarize the evidence and explore potential reasons for statistical heterogeneity. 
If outcome measures do not show too many variations (I² = 20-60%), prevalence and incidence rates will be calculated by pooling the study-specific effect-estimates using random-effects models. If I² <20%, we will claim homogeneity and change the decision to fixed-effects models.
Meta-analytic pooling will be conducted if at least three studies report the respective outcome parameter.  In case of interventional studies with a focus on mental health, only the data of the baseline assessment prior to the intervention will be analysed. 
Rates resulting from meta-analytic pooling will be reported as percentages with corresponding 95% CI. 
To evaluate potential moderators, we will extract all investigated moderators from the included studies and systematically prepare them to identify potential relationships. If possible, meta-regressions will be calculated for continuous predictors in a random effects model. Meta-regression models (estimates, z-values, p-values), I² and τ² will be reported. If a quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, the results will be reported descriptively, considering the strength of the studies and by summarizing the (significant) moderators found.
If there is a substantial heterogeneity in the population sample (I² > 60) and categorial predictors, we will perform subgroup analyses, in order to identify potential sources that can explain the substantial heterogeneity. 
Subgroup analyses will be conducted if at least three studies deal with the respective categories. 
Sensitivity analyses will be conducted to examine the robustness of the results of the main outcomes. Further sensitivity analyses are planned for the quality of studies: We will exclude studies with a high risk of bias.

q22.value: Narrative reviews and case reports will be excluded.

q23.value: Study authors will be contacted in case of missing data. If, despite demand, we do not receive missing data, the study will be excluded.

q25.value:
We developed a risk of bias tool based on the Newcastle Ottawa scale (NOS) and the recommendations of the Cochrane Collaboration for the assessment of the risk of bias for non-comparative studies. The tool assesses the following 6 domains: (1) Sample representativeness (1 point), (2) prospective scheduling (1 point), (3) transparent, non-selected reporting of sample characteristics and outcomes (1 point), (4) sample size (1 point), (5) assessment of PTSD/PTSS and CD (4 points), (6) comparability (1 point). A total of 9 points can be reached within these 6 domains. Afterwards the studies will be classified into the groups ‘high risk of bias’ (1-3 points), ‘moderate risk of bias’ (4-6 points) or ‘low risk of bias’ (7-9 points). 
The risk of bias will be assessed independently and according to the study design by two independent researchers (FL and PG). Disagreements in the scoring between the two reviewers will be resolved by discussion, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary.
The presence of publication bias will be graphically examined using funnel plots, if at least 10 studies are to be included. In case of visual asymmetry, we will investigate any possible reasons.

In order to achieve a high quality of this systematic review and meta-analysis, the final review will be evaluated using the checklist for the report of a systematic review (PRISMA statement for systematic reviews and meta-analysis).

If changes or amendments to this study protocol are made, they will be reported.

b) incidence of PTSD and PTSS following a CD event?
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We developed a sensitive search strategy, meaning we seek for all existing literature according to our review question/s.
registration_responses.q22: Narrative reviews and case reports will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Study authors will be contacted in case of missing data. If, despite demand, we do not receive missing data, the study will be excluded.
registration_responses.q25:
We developed a risk of bias tool based on the Newcastle Ottawa scale (NOS) and the recommendations of the Cochrane Collaboration for the assessment of the risk of bias for non-comparative studies. The tool assesses the following 6 domains: (1) Sample representativeness (1 point), (2) prospective scheduling (1 point), (3) transparent, non-selected reporting of sample characteristics and outcomes (1 point), (4) sample size (1 point), (5) assessment of PTSD/PTSS and CD (4 points), (6) comparability (1 point). A total of 9 points can be reached within these 6 domains. Afterwards the studies will be classified into the groups ‘high risk of bias’ (1-3 points), ‘moderate risk of bias’ (4-6 points) or ‘low risk of bias’ (7-9 points). 
The risk of bias will be assessed independently and according to the study design by two independent researchers (FL and PG). Disagreements in the scoring between the two reviewers will be resolved by discussion, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary.
The presence of publication bias will be graphically examined using funnel plots, if at least 10 studies are to be included. In case of visual asymmetry, we will investigate any possible reasons.

In order to achieve a high quality of this systematic review and meta-analysis, the final review will be evaluated using the checklist for the report of a systematic review (PRISMA statement for systematic reviews and meta-analysis).

If changes or amendments to this study protocol are made, they will be reported.
registration_responses.q8.question: A systematic review and meta-analysis
registration_responses.q12.question: PsycINFO, MEDLINE, and EMBASE will be searched by two independent reviewers (PG & FL) for relevant studies reporting prevalence and/or incidence rates in people with CD with no restriction on publication date, publication status, study type and country with a set of pre-established search strings. Disagreements about eligibility will be discussed, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary. Reference lists of all included studies as well as relevant systematic reviews and meta-analyses will be checked for eligible studies. Eligible studies have to be published in English or German. In case no complete text is available, authors will be contacted. If the full text is still not available, the study will be excluded. If there are studies reporting the same outcome based on the same population sample, only the most comprehensive publication will be included. Only studies in human populations will be included.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Main Outcome/s:
Point (≤ 4 weeks), 12-months and lifetime prevalence rate of PTSD and PTSS in people with CD as well as 12-months incidence rate of PTSD and PTSS following a CD event.
Timing and effect measures: Any time-point regarding research question 1 and 3a; regarding research question 2 and 3b: PTSD/PTSS have to be assessed after an CD event occurred.

Additional Outcome/s:
Identification of possible moderators of (a) prevalence and (b) incidence rates: The third review question will be explorative and data-driven. We do not define relevant moderators in advance, but we will extract all investigated moderators from the included studies and prepare them systematically to identify potential relationships.
registration_responses.q19.question:
After duplicate removal, all titles and abstracts identified in the searches will be screened. All papers selected from this step will be reviewed in full text and checked for eligibility criteria
Study selection and data extraction will be conducted by two researchers independently (FL & PG). Disagreements will be resolved by discussion, involving a third reviewer (LS) if necessary.
In case of multiple outcome measures for the assessment of PTSD/PTSS and CD, data will be extracted according to the following hierarchy: Structured interviews, self-report questionnaires, diagnosis by health care professionals, observer assessment. In case of outcome measures of the same hierarchy level, the most commonly used measure across all included studies will be selected or, if not applicable, one outcome measure is randomly selected.
Extracted data will be cross-checked for completeness.

Data analyses will be performed using Review Manager 5.3. 
Forest plots will be created and used to visually investigate statistical heterogeneity. We will use the I² statistics to quantify statistical heterogeneity across studies. In this review the statistical heterogeneity will be regarded as substantial with an I² > 60%. Only studies showing less than substantial statistical heterogeneity (0-60%) will be pooled. In case of substantial statistical heterogeneity, we will abstain from meta-analytical pooling of outcomes across studies and will only report the range of prevalence and incidence rates, descriptively summarize the evidence and explore potential reasons for statistical heterogeneity. 
If outcome measures do not show too many variations (I² = 20-60%), prevalence and incidence rates will be calculated by pooling the study-specific effect-estimates using random-effects models. If I² <20%, we will claim homogeneity and change the decision to fixed-effects models.
Meta-analytic pooling will be conducted if at least three studies report the respective outcome parameter.  In case of interventional studies with a focus on mental health, only the data of the baseline assessment prior to the intervention will be analysed. 
Rates resulting from meta-analytic pooling will be reported as percentages with corresponding 95% CI. 
To evaluate potential moderators, we will extract all investigated moderators from the included studies and systematically prepare them to identify potential relationships. If possible, meta-regressions will be calculated for continuous predictors in a random effects model. Meta-regression models (estimates, z-values, p-values), I² and τ² will be reported. If a quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, the results will be reported descriptively, considering the strength of the studies and by summarizing the (significant) moderators found.
If there is a substantial heterogeneity in the population sample (I² > 60) and categorial predictors, we will perform subgroup analyses, in order to identify potential sources that can explain the substantial heterogeneity. 
Subgroup analyses will be conducted if at least three studies deal with the respective categories. 
Sensitivity analyses will be conducted to examine the robustness of the results of the main outcomes. Further sensitivity analyses are planned for the quality of studies: We will exclude studies with a high risk of bias.

attributes.title: Standing out or fitting in: How gender imbalances emerge among those at the very top

q1.value: Standing out or fitting in: How gender imbalances emerge among those at the very top

q3.value:
Past research in developmental and cognitive sciences has extensively examined gender differences in academic performance (e.g., Hyde & Mertz, 2009; O’Dea, Lagisz, Jennions, & Nakagawa, 2018) and cognitive abilities (e.g., Hedges & Norwell, 1995). Most of these studies – especially those that are more recent and examine larger datasets and sample sizes (e.g., O’Dea et al., 2018) – have concluded that, on average, girls’ academic performance is at similar levels or higher levels when compared to that of boys. Even in subjects such as mathematics, which has been stereotypically associated with boys performing better at, girls’ average performance is not significantly different from that of boys (Hyde & Mertz, 2009). For example, in Hyde and Mertz’s examination (2009) of over seven million children's and youth’s math performance in school, they found that gender differences were near zero in all tested grades, ranging from grade two to grade eleven, and in all tested ethnicities, including African Americans, American Indians, Asian Americans, Latinos, and Whites.

Many studies that examine gender differences in average performance also examine gender differences in variability of performance (e.g., Hedges & Norwell, 1995; Hyde & Mertz, 2009; O’Dea et al., 2018). Several studies looking at a variety of different kinds of performance (e.g., math tests, science tests, spatial cognition, reading tests, school grades in STEM and non-STEM subjects) with large and diverse samples have found greater variability in boys’ performance when compared to that of girls (Hedges & Norwell, 1995; Hyde & Mertz, 2009; Machin & Pekkarinen, 2008). Greater variability leads to increased gender imbalances among those at the very top. For example, Hedges and Norwell (1995) found that in a dataset of over 70,000 15-year-olds, the male-to-female ratio was 1.3 in the top 10%, 1.5 in the top 5%, 2.1 in the top 3%, and 7.0 in the top 1%.

Given how such an imbalance constrains girls' development and contributes to stereotypes associating males with brilliance, we want to research why and when girls choose not to stand out and try to perform at the highest levels. In this study, our research aims to investigate the developmental roots of why there are more top-performing males than females in various STEM and non-STEM fields. Specifically, do gender differences emerge in how willing children are to try to perform at the highest levels? If so, when do these gender differences emerge and how do they develop across time? Why might these differences emerge (e.g., differences in persistence, differences in willingness to share performance with others, etc.)? 

Please refer to the "Study design" section for a detailed description of the study procedure and a full list of research questions.

q4.value: We predict that there will be an interaction effect between child gender (boy or girl) and condition (top or average) in both children's persistence and their willingness to share performance with peers and their best friends. Specifically, we predict that boys in the top condition will persist more and be more willing to share their performance with peers and their best friends than girls, while boys in the average condition will persist less and be less willing to share their performance with peers and their best friends than girls. We do not expect to see an interaction effect or main effects of gender or condition in children's willingness to share performance with their parents.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have a between-subject design that we plan to administer to elementary-age students (4th and 5th grade).

Children will be tested independently by an experimenter in quiet classrooms in their school, with materials presented on a tablet computer via Qualtrics.

First, we will use a between-subjects design to randomly assign participants to one of two conditions: top or average. Participants in both conditions will be told that they are invited to participate in a game that will test their understanding of science concepts and asked to type in their full name to help the experimenter remember who has played the game. They are also told that there are five questions total and that they are welcome to answer as many questions as they wish. They are informed that many other children have participated in this game before, so the experimenter will be able to tell them how many other children answered the questions correctly.

Next, participants will be asked Question #1 (for a complete list of questions and the detailed script, please see the attached document "Rarity - Elementary Script - FINAL.docx"). Regardless of how the participant responds, the experimenter will inform the participant that s/he answered correctly. Then, the experimenter will provide feedback information on the participant’s performance, which will differ based on the participant’s assigned condition. Specifically, the experimenter will tell the participant how many other children were also able to answer the question correctly, and correspondingly, how many other children were not able to answer the question correctly (i.e., how many children the participant was able to “beat”). Participants in the top condition will be told that 80% of the children were not able to answer the question correctly, while participants in the average condition will be told that 40% of the children were not able to answer the question correctly. On the computer screen, there will also be a corresponding visual representation of the participant’s performance (for the exact stimuli to be used in the study, please see the attached Qualtrics survey "Rarity_Elementary.qsf"). 

Then, participants will be given the option to continue to Question #2 or to stop playing the game. They are also told that if they continue to Question #2, they will have an opportunity to increase their percentile by five percent (i.e., beat 85% if they are in the top condition or 45% if they are in the average condition) since five percent fewer children were able to answer both Question #1 and Question #2 correctly. If they choose to continue to Questions #2 to #5, the procedure will be identical to that of Question #1, with the only exceptions being that the specific question asked will be different and the feedback provided will be different (please see the attached script and Qualtrics survey). A visual representation of the participant’s performance if s/he chooses to continue will also be shown on the computer screen. Persistence is measured by the number of questions the participant chooses to complete (ranging from 0-4). For this variable, we have a 2 X 2 design between condition (top, average) and participant gender (boy, girl).

After completing the five questions or as many questions as the participant wishes, the participant will be thanked for her/his participation. On the computer screen, the participant’s full name and final percentile will be shown. Then, the participant will be asked (1) if s/he would like to share her/his performance with her/his peers by being included in the classroom bulletin board, (2) if s/he would like to share her/his performance with her/his best friend, and (3) if s/he would like to share her/his performance with her/his parents through a parent letter that explains the game that was played and includes the participant’s performance on it. Participants’ willingness to publicize their performance with peers, their best friend, and their parents, respectively, is measured by their binary choices on these three questions. For these three variables, we also have a 2 X 2 design between condition (top, average) and participant gender (boy, girl).

In the end, the experimenter will thank the participant again for her/his participation and explain that because they do not want to hurt the feelings of other students, a bulletin board about this game will not be made and the parent letter will not be sent.

q9.value: We will randomly assign participants to one of two study conditions: top or average. Randomization will be programmed through Qualtrics so that an even number of participants will be randomly assigned to each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit a total of 128 children (50% female) from grades 4 and 5 in New York City public elementary schools, with 64 children (32 boys and 32 girls) in each condition. All procedures are approved by the Institutional Review Board at New York University.

q14.value: We determined this sample size based on the number of consent forms that were returned to us at the elementary schools.

q15.value: We will stop data collection once we test all the children in our expected sample.

question.value: We will manipulate the feedback information that participants receive on their performance. For participants assigned to the top condition, they will be told that they outperform 80% children after Question #1, 85% after Question #2, 90% after Question #3, 95% after Question #4, and 100% after Question #5. For participants assigned to the average condition, they will be told that they outperform 40% children after Question #1, 45% after Question #2, 50% after Question #3, 55% after Question #4, and 60% after Question #5.

1. Outcome measure: Children's persistence (measured by the number of questions that the child chooses to continue to answer)
Scale: 0-4 
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction

2. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with peers
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction

3. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with best friend
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction

4. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with parents
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction

1. Outcome measure: Children's persistence (measured by the number of questions that the child chooses to continue to answer)
Scale: 0-4 
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction
Analysis: Negative binomial generalized linear mixed-effects model in which participant gender (male, female; effect-coded with female = -1), condition (top, average; effect-coded with average = -1), and interaction between participant gender and condition are the primary fixed-effects of interest, with random intercepts by participant ID

2. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with peers
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction
Analysis: Generalized linear mixed-effects model with a binomial distribution in which participant gender (male, female; effect-coded with female = -1), condition (top, average; effect-coded with average = -1), and interaction between participant gender and condition are the primary fixed-effects of interest, with random intercepts by participant ID

3. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with best friend
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction
Analysis: Generalized linear mixed-effects model with a binomial distribution in which participant gender (male, female; effect-coded with female = -1), condition (top, average; effect-coded with average = -1), and interaction between participant gender and condition are the primary fixed-effects of interest, with random intercepts by participant ID


4. Outcome measure: Children's willingness to share performance with parents
Covariates: Condition (top, average), participant gender, condition*participant gender interaction
Analysis: Generalized linear mixed-effects model with a binomial distribution in which participant gender (male, female; effect-coded with female = -1), condition (top, average; effect-coded with average = -1), and interaction between participant gender and condition are the primary fixed-effects of interest, with random intercepts by participant ID

However, given that our surveys are offline and do not rely on Wi-Fi connection, and also given that the children will be wearing headphones and will be in a separate classroom during testing, we do not anticipate these scenarios to happen very often, if at all.

attributes.title: Reading Aloud and False Memory (Within Subjects)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We plan to test 80 participants based on the sample of our previous, similar production study.

analyses.value:
We will use 2x2 within-subjects ANOVA (word type: studied vs critical lure, word presentation: aloud vs heard) on recognition rates. We will follow up with paired samples t-test to compare the false recognition rates as well as true recognition rates in the two conditions. 

We will also use 2x2x2 within-subjects ANOVA (word type: studied vs critical lure, word presentation: aloud vs heard, response: remember vs know) on proportion of remember/know responses. We will follow up with paired t-tests.

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who did not follow instructions during the experiment. Also, participants whose mean recognition of the studied items is worse than 2 standard deviations below the mean will also be excluded.

Excluded participants will be replaced.

conditions.value: The experiment is a within-subject design with two conditions: the read-aloud condition and the hear condition. Participants will view all words visually (a random half presented in red and the other half in blue), and read aloud words presented in one color and hear words in the other color (counterbalanced).

hypothesis.value: Will producing items aloud (i.e., reading words aloud) influence false memory rates compared to hearing words spoken aloud?
